WorkItem.ClosedComment: If you want to concatenate, the best way in JavaScript is to use a step in the toolchain which handles concatenation.  This is generally more flexible, and better supported, than using preprocessor directives in the source code.
WorkItem.Description:
I bring [this question from StackOverflow][1] to here because I think there is no way to deal with some statements like:

    #import "file.js"

and possibly other statements in other dialects of javascript like [Apple's UIAutomation][2].

I think a solution would be to add some compiler directives. That would tell TypeScript not to process a certain piece of code but just copy it into the result js file. 
I imagine something like GCC's pragmas (?)

  [1]:http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12916483/typescript-with-uiautomation-apples-library/12917670#12917670
  [2]:http://developer.apple.com/library/ios/#documentation/DeveloperTools/Reference/UIAutomationRef/_index.html
